title: 歸田園居
text:
Recent visit to a large, modern, metropolitan area confirmed a theory.
A suspicion that has been building and partially tested over the years.
I have become a country mouse than a city mouse.
All of the modern conveniences were present.
Clean, well organized streets with buses and subways that served virtually all parts of the city.
Law abiding citizens, adding to the sense of well being and safety.
Modern office and apartment buildings that housed hundreds if not thousand persons in a single edifice.
Places that will satisfy basics as well as un-stated needs in an instant.
In fact, the only thing missing were more customers that will consume all of the material goods that were readily available in this metropolitan area and beyond.
There were few things that I needed coaching up to become more like the citizen of this city.
Like navigating the maze of the underground transportation system. Calling taxis using the new peer to peer network. Ordering food through installed kiosks at each table.
In time, I would become more proficient and could mimic being a local person.
However, there was one trend that proved to be difficult to overlook.
Tasks in big city were mostly transactional.
No room, or more accurately no time for getting personal or have a human interaction.
In an area, covered with as if 人山人海, I felt alone. Tides of people in the morning and even more people in the evening hours.
I would not know how to adjust to this setting where people appear to congregate and get things done, then retire to their areas of refuge, into their cubicles in the sky.
I could adjust, but given a choice, I will take a small town with its inconveniences over a big town living.
談的談 說的說
小城故事真不錯
請你的朋友一起來
小城來做客
Talking here, and chatting there,
Small town stories are so fine.
Bring your friends along with you,
Come and spend some time.

title: Center of Learning
text:
Kyoto (京都) has its temples and shrines.
Suzhou (蘇州 or 苏州) has canals and gardens.
An Dong (안동시/安東市) has its share of 한옥1 and 서원
경주 and 셔울 has administrative, cultural, religious palaces and temples.
However, 안동 has preserved 서원
Similar to temples and shrines, 서원s are usually built on a hill over looking cities or rivers, in a series of building and gates.
These buildings of learning and housing are configured, connected, and positioned to resembles one’s journey in life.
A series of experiences or trials followed by an entry into a higher level of understanding. Symbolically represented by series of gates and a rise in elevation.
서원 layout link
Classical Gardens of Suzhou represents nature or order of universe and symbolically captures universal elements of life taught through Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism2.
拙政園 Humble Administrator’s Garden link
서원, the place of learning set in nature, combines the setting and intent of temples, shrines, and gardens.
Nature both teaches and confirms learning and attainment. By visiting these places, one can assess the understanding of men and his place in the society and the universe.
That our daily struggles and growth may be small but a significant step towards a destined place, passing through men or god instituted tests and trials and receiving due attainment.

title: Center of Learning
section: Appendix A: An Overview of Classical Gardens
text:
Appendix A: An Overview of Classical Gardens
Key Features of Suzhou Gardens Small-scale but highly artistic design
Unlike imperial gardens (e.g., in Beijing), Suzhou gardens are private and intimate, designed for reflection and scholarly life.
Principles of design
“Borrowed scenery” (借景): Use of background elements outside the garden.
Balance of elements: Rocks (symbolizing mountains), water (lakes or ponds), plants, and architecture.
Architecture and space
Pavilions, bridges, zigzag corridors, moon gates, lattice windows.
Designed for framing views, seasonal change, and poetic composition.
Symbolism
Every element often holds cultural or philosophical meaning, especially from Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism.

section: Appendix B: AI Explanation of 한옥
text:
Appendix B: AI Explanation of 한옥
한옥(韓屋)은 한국의 전통적인 건축 양식으로 지어진 집을 의미합니다. 주로 나무, 흙, 돌, 짚 등을 사용하여 지어지며, 온돌, 대청마루 등 특징적인 구조를 가지고 있습니다. 넓은 의미로는 초가집, 너와집 등 모든 전통 가옥을 포함하지만, 일반적으로는 기와집 형태의 한옥을 떠올리는 경우가 많습니다. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]
한옥의 특징:
• 온돌: 구들을 이용해 바닥 난방을 하는 한국 고유의 난방 방식입니다. [7, 7, 8, 8]
• 대청마루: 거실과 같이 넓은 공간으로, 여름철 시원하게 지낼 수 있는 공간입니다. [7, 7, 9, 9, 10, 11, 12]
• 처마: 지붕의 끝 부분이 건물 밖으로 길게 뻗어 나와 여름철 햇볕을 가려주고 겨울철에는 눈과 비를 막아줍니다. [7, 7, 13, 13]
• 자연과의 조화: 풍수지리 사상에 따라 자연 환경과 조화를 이루도록 지어지며, 뒤로는 산을 등지고 앞으로는 물을 바라보는 방향으로 짓는 것이 일반적입니다. [1, 1, 14, 14]
한옥의 종류:
• 초가집: 짚으로 지붕을 이은 집입니다. • 너와집: 나무 판자를 엮어 지붕을 이은 집입니다. • 기와집: 기와로 지붕을 이은 집입니다. [5, 5, 7, 7]
한옥의 장점:
• 친환경적인 건축 재료: 나무, 흙, 돌 등 자연 재료를 사용하여 건강하고 쾌적한 주거 환경을 제공합니다. [2, 2, 5, 5]
• 온돌 난방 시스템: 겨울철 따뜻하고 편안한 난방을 제공합니다. [2, 2, 8, 8, 15]
• 자연과의 조화: 주변 환경과 잘 어울리고 자연의 변화를 느낄 수 있습니다. [1, 1, 14, 14, 16, 17, 18]
• 독특한 아름다움: 전통적인 선과 구조에서 나오는 아름다움을 가지고 있습니다. [13, 13, 19, 19]
최근 한옥의 변화: 최근에는 현대적인 생활 방식에 맞춰 한옥을 개량하거나 새로운 한옥을 짓는 시도가 이루어지고 있습니다. 전통적인 요소를 유지하면서 편리성을 높이고, 현대적인 디자인을 가미하여 새로운 형태의 한옥이 등장하고 있습니다. [20, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25]
AI responses may include mistakes.

title: Convenience and Comfort
text:
Traveled to a place where food was fit for Goldilocks.
It wasn’t too spicy, too salty, but just right.
Took many photos, they came out better than I expected.
In fact, all of them were technically just right, as algorithm dictated it to be.
Didn’t have to make any travel plans.
Hosts took care of it, I just had to be ready and they chauffeured me from places to places using the latest navigation tools.

Consequently, I didn’t get lost nor went to a bad eating establishment.
Then again, I never learned how to figure out directions or where I was visiting.
By looking at metadata on photos, I could retrace places I visited.
In the days past, I would be asking directions even after pouring over maps.
Looking for landmarks, such as banks or natural indicators.
Also consulting the position of the sun to determine the direction in the absence of landmarks.
This approach was mistake-prone but after a day or so, one usually figured out the lay of the land.
Food was not only presented well and flavored ideally, but also there were over abundance of it.
Growing up, food was scarce and meals were served plain with mostly vegetables, fishes and occasional meat enhanced soups.
Food was local and seldom got to taste cuisine from other locations
We tasted meat, a couple times a year, usually during holidays or birthdays of older people.
On a recent trip, we got to sample food from all regions of the country, while in the capital city.
Special occasion food was available on-demand, all hours of the day.
One could eat food from days gone by as well as order food that was from other countries.
A wedding banquet featured total of 5 buffet lines.
A line of traditional Korean food, followed by seafood selection, fruit and salad, and dessert.
An hour and half allotted time was not enough to sample all the food and visit with relatives.
(in the wedding venues, scheduled are tightly set and each couple has 30 to 40 minutes to use the main hall and guests are directed to the dining hall afterwards, before the next couple starts their cycle of activities).

The society had transformed from scarcity and inconvenient mode to one of utmost abundance and comfort.
During 50 years, the pace of growth and transformation has been remarkable.
Kudos to the people of Korea their achievements that borders on miracle.
As an aged observer, it seemed that in days of past, one was faced with daily challenges and inconvenience.
Lack of food and walk to nearly all places.
Now days, there are more food than the population 2 or 3 times can consume.
In addition, one has to look for ways to exercise, find a way to walk to places and rely on personal navigation skills rather than rely on electronic help.

Not suggesting that those days were preferable to today.
Days of poverty, hunger and physical demands
But in some ways, discomfort, pain and hardship developed character and appreciation.
There must be ways to earn it in these Goldilocks days.
If you know of a way, please let me know, I need a reminder.
Provo,
July 2025

title: Return Trip to Bountiful
text:
손자(孫子):
Hi Grandpa, came across some digital photos from the year of the Snake (乙巳)1.
Wasn’t this the period when you were slowing down and transitioning from company funded trips?
The photos told a different story.
Older Me:
That was the year the oldest of your maternal uncles got married, Uncle JH.
Yes, that was post company sponsored travel days. And I thought of taking things slower but your grandma had other ideas.
She was invited to the wedding in Korea and scheduled to travel there.
But I wasn’t – initially.
Like many things in life, women’s willpower changes the outcome.
Soon, I was making travel plans and thinking of people and places to meet and visit.
손자(孫子):
So how did you go about detailed planning? Without specifics of business trips.
Older Me:
We have visited Korea a number of times, but this was the first time only 2 of us traveled.
At that time we had sold the business that required the attention of grandma. Because I was working at the time, chose a 10-day visit duration. Planned around the wedding.
That opened up many options and possibilities.
In addition, a direct flight to Incheon, Korea, had begun just few weeks prior to the visit.2
I had a number of aunts and uncle that were in their 80s and 90s.
My mother’s younger siblings in Korea were, 90 and 87.
My father’s youngest brother was 82.
My mother’s church friend was 90.
Visiting them was my priority.
Plus I wanted to visit my hometown 인천(仁川).
The remaining time would be spent either shopping or visiting sites around the country.
I didn’t know how we could do all of this in 10 days.
We decided to visit 서울성전 at the beginning and at the end of our visit.
And met with the uncle and aunts, the first 4 days we were in Korea.
손자(孫子):
I do remember stories about your aunts and uncles.
I am glad you kept in touch with them over the years.
How did you get in touch with Grandma’s friends, after she had passed away?
Older Me:
We formed a group, LLJK, (이이정강).
We first met in 인천, during the early days of the Church in the area.
We had maintained our friendship with the help of the group chat.
All but L1 had moved to the States, when I told L2 and J that I would be traveling to Korea, they suggested I get in touch with L1, who lived in 마포 area of 서울
L2 warned me that there aren’t many people that would remember me and advised me to visit and enjoy the local food.
L1 met me on a day that was 90+ degrees Farenheit and same amount of humidity.
I wanted to meet my aunt first and then tour the town.
I wondered why he kept avoiding a lunchtime rendenvous
As a compromise, we met at 9AM at 동인천역(東仁川駅)
By 10AM the weather was brutal, I was struggling with the heat and the hilly streets
As we walked, L1 rehearsed the history and people associated with the church in Incheon (인천)
Started in 중앙동, in a rented, converted 2-story building. Recall, one of the floor had a tatami (畳) floor.
Then a government property3 in 답동 was purchased and the existing building was renovated for church use.
Subsequently a new building was built on site. Eventually, all of the 인천 area wards were combined into a single meeting house in 주안.
손자(孫子):
Quite a day. You were lucky that L2 was available and willing to take you to places. How did it feel to walk around the places of birth and growth?
Older Me:
Things had changed dramatically in last 50 years. Except for few places that hadn’t changed, it was like many other places in modern Korea. Vertical growth and no green areas. Almost a feeling of visiting a foreign country.
Except, the memories of people and experiences. Meetings and activities in the old chapel.
Friends that still remember who I was and accept me as who I have become.
손자(孫子):
So did you visit your old church on Sunday?
Older Me:
Yes, I visited 인천1와드. That Ward was composed of the former, 답동, 송도, 주안 Wards
As we were driving towards the new building, I related the conversion story of my mother.
She had studied with the missionaries for nearly 2 years. But she still had some questions. She wrote them down.
When Harold B. Lee visited Korea and my mother attended the fireside All of mother’s questions were answered by the visiting general authority. Mom’s mind was set to join the church - intellectually
Then one afternoon, she dreamed a dream.
In the dream, there were 2 books. She could tell they were the Bible and the Book of Mormon. And a hand appeared and pointing to 2 books and touching them one by one said
She was ready to be baptized.
손자(孫子):
Thanks for sharing that. So did anyone recognize you?
Older Me:
L2 was correct, in a congregation of nearly 150 people only 3 people knew me. L2’s mother. L1’s sister and her husband.
I wondered if this will be similar to how we will be welcomed into the next life. There will be we may know and recognize but only a few would personally escort us through.
That person this time was L2’s mom.
She recounted how she and my mother served in the Stake Primary Presidency, without really understandint the calling.
Then she recounted my mother’s dream about the hand and 2 books. Almost word for word.
My testimony was strengthened. I had come home to my and my family’s Bountiful.
Thank you members of the 인천 area. In particular, thank you Sister 임윤님, Brother 유관종, Sister 이강주. For remembering me, welcoming me, and confirming the faith of my parents.
